Article Title: Android co-founder to Bill Gates: So, sorry Bill, you're more responsible for Microsoft losing the $400 billion than you realize
Article Text:
Bill Gates

Android co-founder Rich Miner has responded to Bill Gates ' admission about Microsoft 's $400 billion mobile market failure , stating that Gates himself was largely responsible for losing the smartphone wars to Android."I literally helped create Android to prevent Microsoft from controlling the phone the way they did the PC - stifling innovation. So it's always funny for me to hear Gates whine about losing mobile to Android," Miner wrote on X (formerly), responding to Gates' comments about Microsoft's biggest mistake.Miner, who has firsthand experience with both sides of the mobile ecosystem, revealed he had concerns about Microsoft's potential monopolistic control of the mobile market while working on the first Windows Mobile phone."I helped Orange launch the first Windows Mobile phone in 2002, the SPV. I worried MSFT might end up controlling mobile like they did the PC, I wanted something more open. So, sorry Bill, you're more responsible for loosing the $400B than you realize," Miner stated.His comments came after Gates admitted in an interview with Eventbrite CEO Julia Hartz that Microsoft's failure to become the dominant non-Apple mobile platform was "one of the greatest mistakes of all time." Gates estimated this mistake cost Microsoft approximately $400 billion in potential market value, which instead went to Google's Android platform.The timing of market entry proved crucial in the mobile platform wars. While Apple launched the iPhone in June 2007 and Google's Android followed in September 2008, Microsoft didn't release Windows Phone 7 until October 2010. This delay contributed to Android and Apple eventually capturing 99.9 percent of the mobile market share.
Article Summary: Android co-founder Rich Miner has responded to Bill Gates'admission about Microsoft's $400 billion mobile market failure. Miner revealed he had concerns about Microsoft's potential monopolistic control of the mobile market while working on the first Windows Mobile phone.

Article Title: Meta layoffs: Mark Zuckerberg announces 5% job cuts at Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp; “we typically …,” reads internal memo
Article Text:
According to a 404 Media report, many employees have described the move as "unacceptable" and "appalling” in leaked internal discussions

Meta announced plans to lay off approximately 3,600 employees, or 5% of its workforce, as part of CEO Mark Zuckerberg's push to "raise the bar on performance management" at the social media giant.In an internal memo sent to staff, Zuckerberg emphasized the need for an accelerated approach to removing underperforming employees. "We typically manage out people who aren't meeting expectations over the course of a year, but now we're going to do more extensive performance-based cuts during this cycle," he wrote.The cuts, scheduled to begin February 10 for U.S.-based employees, come amid what Zuckerberg called "an intense year" focused on "building some of the most important technologies in the world — AI, glasses as the next computing platform, and the future of social media."Hillary Champion, Meta's director of people development growth programs, detailed in a separate memo that employees receiving "Met Some" or "Did Not Meet" performance ratings would be "automatically added to the performance termination list." The company aims to reach 10% non-regrettable attrition, combining last year's 5% with an additional 5% this year.The announcement sparked concern among employees, with some questioning the accuracy of the performance review system. "I would say the ratings and process creates marginally better than 'monkey's throwing darts' in terms of reflecting the actual performance and impact," one employee wrote on an internal message board.Others worried about the timing of the cuts, which follow recent changes at Meta, including the rollback of diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives and the disbanding of its third-party fact-checking program. "Teams aren't exactly strong when morale is low, and this is already a pretty rough ride over the last week," another employee noted.Meta plans to backfill the terminated positions in 2025, and affected employees will receive "generous severance packages ," according to Champion's memo.The latest cuts follow previous layoffs of 21,000 workers between 2022 and 2023.
Article Summary: Meta announced plans to lay off approximately 3,600 employees, or 5% of its workforce. The cuts, scheduled to begin February 10 for U.S.-based employees, come amid what CEO Mark Zuckerberg called "an intense year" Zuckerberg emphasized the need for an accelerated approach to removing underperforming employees.

Article Title: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle slam Mark Zuckerberg, say “destroying democracy” with changes at Facebook and Instagram
Article Text:
Prince Harry and Meghan Markle

Prince Harry and Meghan Markle have criticized Meta 's significant rollback of its fact-checking program and content moderation policies, joining a growing number of public figures voicing concerns about the implications for online safety and democracy.In a statement released online, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex criticized Meta's decision to end its third-party fact-checking program and loosen content moderation rules, arguing these changes "directly undermine free speech" despite the company's claims to the contrary."Meta's changes to its 'Hateful Content Policies' do not protect free expression but instead foster an environment where abuse and hate speech silence and threaten the voices of whole communities who make up a healthy democracy," the couple stated.Under new chief global affairs officer Joel Kaplan, Meta is shifting to a Community Notes model and lifting restrictions on what it calls "topics that are part of mainstream discourse."The Archewell Foundation also expressed concern over Meta's plans to abandon commitments to diversity and equity, coupled with internal policy changes affecting marginalized communities. These decisions, they noted, align with warnings from experts and families about how platform design impacts online safety, especially for children.The Sussexes' statement emphasized the global implications of Meta's policy changes, arguing that "the politics of one country should never determine whether freedom of expression and civil and human rights are protected in the online spaces so clearly shaping or destroying democracy."The royal couple's foundation announced new partnerships and support for organizations working on online safety and accountability, including the Center for Critical Internet Inquiry and Parents Together. They're also collaborating with Screen Sanity to develop safety-by-design education for parents.
Article Summary: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle criticized Meta's rollback of its fact-checking program. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex said the changes "directly undermine free speech" The Archewell Foundation also expressed concern over Meta's plans to abandon diversity and equity.

Article Title: WazirX’s $235 million hack tied to North Korean cyber group; US, Japan, South Korea issues joint statement
Article Text:
Multiple crypto thefts in 2024 attributed to North Korean entities

WazirX, India’s largest cryptocurrency exchange, suffered a significant security breach in July 2024. The breach resulted in the loss of nearly 45% of its crypto asset holdings. Following the breach, the platform halted trading and suspended its operations to address the issue and enhance security measures. In a latest, the US, Japan, and South Korea have jointly attributed the security breach faced by WazirX to North Korea. They allege that North Korean Lazarus Group were behind the attack that compromised one of the exchange’s multisignature wallets.In a joint statement issued January 14, 2025, they said “The Democratic People’s Republic of Korea’s (DPRK) cyber program threatens our three countries and the broader international community and, in particular, poses a significant threat to the integrity and stability of the international financial system.”“Our three governments strive together to prevent thefts, including from private industry, by the DPRK and to recover stolen funds with the ultimate goal of denying the DPRK illicit revenue for its unlawful weapons of mass destruction and ballistic missile programs,” it added.The joint statement also highlights that throughout 2024, the governments of the United States, Japan, and South Korea have repeatedly attributed several virtual asset thefts to North Korean entities.These include “DMM Bitcoin for $308 million, Upbit for $50 million, and Rain Management for $16.13 million. The US and the Republic of Korea additionally attribute to the DPRK, based on detailed industry analysis, thefts last year against WazirX for $235 million and Radiant Capital for $50 million.”In the statement, the US, Japan, and South Korea pledged to counter North Korea’s cyber activities by working together to impose sanctions, strengthen cybersecurity in the Indo-Pacific, and enhance coordination through trilateral working groups to combat threats.
Article Summary: WazirX, India’s largest cryptocurrency exchange, suffered a significant security breach in July 2024. The breach resulted in the loss of nearly 45% of its crypto asset holdings. Take advantage of hints: Pay attention to off-topic words for clues. For every three non-theme words you uncover, letters will be highlighted to give you a hint toward finding a theme word, without directly revealing it.

Article Title: Why Mark Zuckerberg ordered to remove tampons from men's restrooms at Facebook parent Meta’s offices
Article Text:
Why tampons are no longer in Meta’s men’s restrooms

Meta ends DEI programs, shifting to merit-based hiring amid employee concerns

Customization options and LGBTQ+ concerns



Alignment with political shifts



Employee reactions and public criticism



Also read |

|

|

Meta , the parent company of Facebook , Instagram, and Threads, has recently undertaken a series of sweeping changes to its policies and operations. These adjustments, which include decisions affecting diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives, content moderation practices, and facilities management, have sparked widespread discussion. According to reports from Fox News Digital and The New York Times, these changes appear to reflect Meta’s evolving stance on workplace policies and platform governance, prompting a mix of support, criticism, and employee dissatisfaction.One of the most visible policy shifts was the removal of tampons from men’s restrooms across Meta’s offices in Silicon Valley, Texas, and New York. This decision, reported by The New York Times, impacts nonbinary and transgender employees who may require such amenities. The company has not provided detailed explanations for this change, leaving room for speculation and concern among affected staff and advocates.Meta has also revamped its approach to content moderation. In a move toward "restoring free expression," the company ended its third-party fact-checking program in the United States. The program, which had been central to Meta’s efforts to combat misinformation, is being replaced by a "community notes" system similar to the model used by Elon Musk’s X (formerly Twitter). This crowdsourced moderation framework is intended to allow users to collaboratively add context to potentially misleading posts.Critics argue that the elimination of fact-checking may leave the platform vulnerable to the unchecked spread of misinformation. However, Meta contends that the previous system had "gone too far" and impeded open discourse.Meta has discontinued its primary DEI initiatives , a decision that Joel Kaplan, Meta’s Chief Global Affairs Officer, defended as a step toward merit-based hiring. Kaplan stated that recruitment would focus on individual qualifications rather than considerations of race or gender. While Meta frames this shift as a move to promote fairness and broaden candidate pools, internal communications reveal that LGBTQ staff members and other employees have expressed dissatisfaction, with some announcing their departure from the company.The broader implications of this policy change extend beyond recruitment. Critics worry that the absence of structured DEI programs could lead to reduced support for underrepresented groups within Meta’s workforce.Another notable change involves the removal of transgender and nonbinary customization options from the Messenger application. This move has fueled concerns about Meta's commitment to inclusivity. Internal reports indicate that LGBTQ+ employees feel alienated by these decisions, and many have raised questions about the company’s long-term priorities regarding diversity and inclusion.These policy changes come amid what many observers see as a broader alignment with the political climate in the United States, particularly with the incoming administration of President-elect Donald Trump. Critics suggest that Meta’s decisions may reflect a strategic effort to gain favor with the administration by adopting positions that align with its ideological leanings. This perception is further reinforced by the company’s public emphasis on restoring "free expression" and its distancing from progressive DEI initiatives.Internally, the response from Meta employees has been mixed. While some staff members view the changes as necessary to streamline operations and foster innovation, others feel disillusioned by what they see as a retreat from Meta’s prior commitments to inclusivity and progressive values.Externally, Meta’s actions have drawn significant criticism from advocacy groups, public figures, and industry analysts. Some argue that these changes undermine the progress made in fostering a more equitable workplace and responsible content moderation practices.
Article Summary: Facebook's parent company, Meta, has made a series of changes to its policies and operations. These include decisions affecting diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives, content moderation practices, and facilities management. These changes have sparked a mix of support, criticism, and employee dissatisfaction.

This move reflects the company’s ambition to become a major player in the electronics manufacturing services (EMS) sector.“Tata Electronics has realised that in order to be a top player in the electronics manufacturing services (EMS) ecosystem, it has to focus on scale now,” The Economic Times cited industry sources as saying.“They are actively engaged in discussions with leading Chinese smartphone manufacturers, including Xiaomi and Oppo, to initiate component manufacturing,” one of the sources said.While initial talks with Vivo were underway, the company's recent joint venture with Dixon Technologies has likely precluded this collaboration.“They were initially also in talks with Vivo, but it is unlikely that the Vivo partnership will go through as they have entered into a joint venture with Dixon,” the source told ET.The partnership between Vivo and Dixon Technologies, announced last month, will focus on manufacturing electronic devices, including smartphones. Article Title: EU plans to expand TikTok-like probe into Elon Musk-owned X
Article Text:
Scrutiny increased after Musk endorsed chancellor candidate Alice Weidel

Concerns over foreign interference in EU elections

The European Union (EU) is considering expanding its investigation into Elon Musk's social media platform, X, over content moderation and political interference. According to Henna Virkkunen, the European Commission's executive vice president, the bloc is working to determine if the platform has violated the content moderation rules.“We are currently assessing if the scope is large enough,” Virkkunen told Bloomberg TV. The Commission initiated formal proceedings against X in December 2023, alleging the platform's failure to adequately address illegal content and disinformation.The EU announced the probe over X allegedly breaking rules on how it handled illegal content and disinformation. This is the first such probe of a major online platform since the region’s Digital Services Act came into force this year.Regulators opened formal infringement proceedings against X, two months after warning the company over how it handled harmful content on its site, the European Commission said in a statement.According to the report by Bloomberg, the scrutiny of X intensified following Musk's public endorsement of far-right figures, including Alice Weidel, a candidate for the Alternative for Germany party.The Commission is investigating whether a recent live-streamed conversation between Musk and Weidel on X unfairly amplified the candidate's visibility, potentially violating the Digital Services Act (DSA).The DSA empowers the EU to impose fines of up to 6% of a company's annual global revenue for violations.The report also said that concerns about foreign interference in EU elections have heightened significantly. Romania's recent annulment of its presidential election, following reports of Russian meddling, including through social media platforms, has prompted increased scrutiny.This situation led the EU to launch a DSA investigation into TikTok, owned by China’s ByteDance, to assess its role in potential interference.
Article Summary: The European Union is considering expanding its investigation into Elon Musk's social media platform, X. The EU announced the probe over X allegedly breaking rules on how it handled illegal content and disinformation. Scrutiny increased after Musk's public endorsement of far-right figures, including Alice Weidel, a candidate for the Alternative for Germany party.

Article Title: Why Microsoft, Google, Amazon and other tech giants have cut some orders of Nvidia’s AI chip system
Article Text:
Jensen Huang with a Blackwell processor (left) and the H100.

Cloud companies waiting for revised versions of AI tech

Microsoft, Google, Amazon’s and Meta, among other buyers of Nvidia’s Blackwell GB200 racks, have reportedly cut some orders as the leading manufacturer of AI chips is encountering challenges with its latest product, the Blackwell chip.According to a report by The Information (via news agency Reuters), major customers like Microsoft, Amazon, Google and Meta have delayed orders of Blackwell-powered server racks due to overheating issues and glitches in chip connectivity.These technical problems have caused concern, leading to a drop of over 4% in Nvidia's stock price during early trading, news agency Reuters reported, adding that the new US restrictions on AI chip exports could further impact Nvidia’s sales.The report details that initial shipments of Blackwell racks have exhibited overheating and communication issues between chips. These racks, used in data centers, house essential equipment like chips and cables.According to the report, major cloud computing companies, also known as hyperscalers, had reportedly placed significant orders for Blackwell racks, with some exceeding $10 billion. But in response to the technical issues, some of them are delaying orders as they either prefer to wait for a revised version of the racks, or opt for older Nvidia AI chips.Moreover, Microsoft, which initially planned to deploy a large number of Blackwell chips – at least 50,000 – in a Phoenix data center, has requested older generation "Hopper" chips from its partner OpenAI due to the delays, the report added.It was previously reported that Nvidia’s highly-anticipated Blackwell AI ‘superchip’ overheated when deployed in high-density server racks designed to accommodate up to 72 chips. Citing sources, The Information reported that Nvidia has repeatedly requested design modifications from its suppliers to address the overheating, but a definitive solution has not been found.Nvidia acknowledged the challenges but downplayed the issue.“Nvidia is working with leading cloud service providers as an integral part of our engineering team and process. The engineering iterations are normal and expected,” a company spokesperson was quoted as saying.

Article Title: Elon Musk accused by California Governor Gavin Newsom over LA fire claims: “Elon Musk exposed by firefighters for his own lies”
Article Text:
Elon Musk’s contributions amid criticism



Gavin Newsom’s leadership under fire



A broader call to action



Also read |

|

The ongoing wildfire crisis in California has ignited a public exchange between Tesla CEO Elon Musk and California Governor Gavin Newsom . Newsom accused Musk of spreading misinformation about water shortages during the deadly wildfires in Los Angeles and nearby regions. The debate underscores the complexities of disaster management , the role of public figures in shaping narratives, and the urgent need to address climate change and wildfire mitigation.In a video shared by Newsom on X (formerly Twitter), a firefighter directly contradicted Musk’s claims about water availability. Musk had recently taken to X to criticize “bad governance” and “overregulation,” alleging that they contributed to water shortages during firefighting efforts. However, the firefighter in the video clarified that water availability was not the issue. He explained that while there was sufficient water, the challenge lay in delivering the high flow rates required to combat such large-scale fires. Mobile hydrants had to be deployed to ensure an adequate supply in the most affected areas, including Malibu and Pacific Palisades.Governor Newsom amplified the video with a sharp caption: “@ElonMusk exposed by firefighters for his own lies.” The post aimed to challenge Musk’s narrative, emphasizing the availability of resources and redirecting the focus to effective disaster response.Amid the criticism, Elon Musk visited the Pacific Palisades on January 12 and made a tangible contribution to the firefighting efforts, as reported. He donated Tesla Cybertrucks equipped with Starlink internet terminals to serve as mobile power and communication hubs for affected areas. While his efforts were praised for their ingenuity, his comments about water shortages drew scrutiny. Critics, including Newsom, argued that the priority should be on immediate relief and long-term solutions rather than assigning blame.While Newsom called out Musk’s statements, his own leadership during the wildfire crisis has come under intense scrutiny. According to reports, President-elect Donald Trump criticized the governor on Truth Social, calling for his resignation and blaming him for the state’s inability to manage the wildfires. Trump’s remarks, paired with mounting public frustration, have put additional pressure on Newsom to deliver results.The governor’s office reported that over 7,500 firefighting personnel have been deployed to combat the blazes, working alongside local and federal partners. Despite these efforts, the death toll has risen to 24, with 16 fatalities linked to the Eaton Fire and 8 to the Palisades Fire. The wildfires have destroyed thousands of homes, leaving communities devastated and prompting renewed discussions about California’s wildfire preparedness and response strategies.As wildfires continue to ravage California, the crisis highlights the intersection of environmental challenges, governance, and technology. Musk’s statements and actions, along with Newsom’s leadership, reflect the complexities of managing natural disasters in an era of increasing climate volatility. The debate underscores the need for collaboration, innovation, and accountability in addressing the root causes of such disasters while ensuring immediate relief for affected communities.The wildfires in California serve as a sobering reminder of the devastating impacts of climate change and the urgent need for effective disaster preparedness and mitigation strategies. As leaders, scientists, and communities grapple with these challenges, the focus must remain on supporting those affected and building a resilient future.
Article Summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom accused Tesla CEO Elon Musk of spreading misinformation about water shortages. Musk had recently taken to X to criticize “bad governance” and “overregulation,” alleging that they contributed to water shortages during firefighting efforts. In a video shared by Newsom, a firefighter directly contradicted Musk’s claims about water availability.

Article Title: How scammers are tricking iPhone users to disable in-built security feature in iMessage
Article Text: Cybercriminals have devised a new phishing scam targeting iPhone users, tricking them into disabling iMessage's built-in phishing protection. According to a report by Bleeping Computer, scammers are exploiting a security feature designed to protect users from malicious links.iMessage automatically disables clickable links in messages from unknown senders to prevent phishing attacks. However, scammers have found a way to bypass this protection by sending deceptive messages that mimic notifications from trusted organisations, such as USPS or toll road authorities. These messages often instruct users to reply with "Y" or similar responses to enable the links, making them appear legitimate.When users respond to these messages, the previously disabled links become clickable, exposing them to potential scams. Additionally, replying to these messages confirms to the scammers that the phone number is active, increasing the likelihood of future attacks.This scam is particularly effective against less tech-savvy individuals who may not recognise the phishing attempt. To protect themselves, iPhone users are advised not to respond to messages from unknown senders and to enable message filtering on their devices. This feature moves messages from unknown contacts into a separate list, making it easier to identify and avoid suspicious messages.
Article Summary: iMessage automatically disables clickable links in messages from unknown senders. Scammers have found a way to bypass this protection by sending deceptive messages that mimic notifications from trusted organisations. These messages often instruct users to reply with "Y" or similar responses to enable the links, making them appear legitimate.

Article Title: The reason for Mark Zuckerberg’s second meeting with Donald Trump may have been revealed
Article Text:
Zuckerberg-Trump’s first meeting was about Biden Administration

Zuckerberg slams Biden Administration

Mark Zuckerberg, the founder and CEO of Meta (formerly Facebook), recently met with Donald Trump for the second time. While the initial purpose of the meeting remained undisclosed, a recent report suggests that the tech executive met with the President-elect in part to mediate a 2021 lawsuit.This lawsuit was filed by Trump against Facebook and Zuckerberg following the suspension of their account on the platform after the January 6th Capitol riot. According to a report by the Wall Street Journal, One of the resolution options being considered is a monetary settlement.This marked Zuckerberg's second meeting with the president-elect’s Mar-a-Lago club within a seven-week period. Previous reports indicated that Zuckerberg parked his private jet next to Trump Force One at Palm Beach International Airport on Friday, January 10.Their first meeting, initiated by Zuckerberg, occurred on Thanksgiving Eve and involved discussions about the incoming administration, according to Meta. According to a New York Post report, Zuckerberg had at least two private phone conversations with Trump over the summer.Since Trump's Election Day win, Zuckerberg has donated $1 million to the president-elect's inaugural fund, ended third-party fact-checking on Facebook, and scrapped Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion policies at the social media company.In July, Meta lifted the remaining restrictions on Trump's Facebook and Instagram accounts imposed after the riot. Article Title: Are Candy Crush and Tinder secretly tracking you? Report reveals shocking privacy breach
Article Text:
Candy Crush and Tinder are spying on users’ locations



How user data is collected and sold?



Importance of securing personal data



Call for greater accountability



Also read |

|

|

|

In today’s connected world, smartphones derive much of their value from the vast array of apps and games they support. These apps, relied upon by millions daily, are the backbone of modern communication, entertainment, and productivity. However, a recent revelation has spotlighted the dark side of this convenience: the vulnerability of user data and privacy. A report by 404 Media, published on January 9, 2025, details a significant data breach at Gravy Analytics, a prominent location data broker. This breach raises serious concerns about how popular apps may be accessing and misusing users’ real-time location data.The breach revealed that apps such as Candy Crush Saga and Tinder, among others, were implicated in providing location data that ended up in the hands of Gravy Analytics. A hacker reportedly accessed terabytes of consumer data stored in the company’s Amazon cloud environment. These data points represent one of the largest known collections of consumer location information, highlighting a disturbing reality: user location data is being systematically collected, sold, and exposed to unauthorized entities.The hacker responsible for the breach shared samples of the stolen data on a Russian forum, claiming to have extracted millions of location points from Gravy Analytics’ database, as reported. These points reportedly spanned locations across the U.S., Europe, and even sensitive regions such as the White House, Kremlin, and military bases. The leaked dataset underscores the vast scale of location tracking and the potential dangers it poses.This breach is especially concerning as it comes on the heels of a Federal Trade Commission (FTC) action against Gravy Analytics and its subsidiary, Venntel. The FTC banned these entities from selling consumer location data without explicit user consent. Despite such regulatory measures, the breach demonstrates how user data remains vulnerable to exploitation, particularly when companies fail to implement robust security measures.According to reports, Gravy Analytics, like many location data brokers, typically does not collect data directly from apps. Instead, they work with ad-serving agencies or intermediaries that gain access to user data on Android and iOS devices. This indirect relationship makes it difficult for users to trace how their data is being used and sold. Popular apps, often installed without careful scrutiny, may request permissions that allow them to track real-time locations, which are then monetized by such agencies.The implications of this practice extend far beyond individual privacy violations. Sensitive locations, including government facilities, religious sites, and private residences, being part of the leaked dataset highlight the potential for misuse in espionage, blackmail, or other malicious activities.While users may have little recourse if their data has already been compromised,there are steps they can take to minimize future risks. Disabling unnecessary permissions during app installations is a crucial first step. For example, if an app does not need access to location data to function, users should deny this permission. For iPhone users, enabling the "Ask Apps Not to Track" feature can provide an added layer of security, limiting apps’ ability to collect and share data.Moreover, users should regularly audit the permissions granted to installed apps and games. Reviewing these settings ensures that only essential permissions are active, reducing the likelihood of unauthorized data collection. Staying informed about app updates and potential security vulnerabilities is equally important, as these may introduce new data-sharing practices.This breach highlights the urgent need for stronger data privacy regulations and enforcement. Platforms like Gravy Analytics operate in a largely unregulated space, exploiting loopholes to collect and monetize user data without sufficient oversight. The involvement of high-profile apps in this process underscores the responsibility of app developers to prioritize user privacy and security.For the general public, this incident serves as a wake-up call about the risks of unchecked permissions and the importance of digital hygiene. As reliance on smartphones and apps continues to grow, so does the need for robust safeguards to protect personal information from falling into the wrong hands.
Article Summary: A hacker reportedly accessed terabytes of consumer data stored in the company’s Amazon cloud environment. These data points represent one of the largest known collections of consumer location information. Sensitive locations, including government facilities, religious sites, and private residences, being part of the leaked dataset highlight the potential for misuse.

Article Title: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy has a new “shadow” advisor and why he may be among Amazon's next CEO picks

Article Title: Paytm CEO Vijay Shekhar Sharma warns of AI's growing impact on social media: “"You won’t know if you are talking to a human or a bot"
Article Text:
Vijay Shekhar Sharma’s concerns about AI’s authenticity on social media



The growing influence of AI on social media platforms



The prevalence of AI in digital conversations



Also read |

|

|

|

The rapid emergence and integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into digital platforms have sparked significant debates about its impact on online authenticity. Vijay Shekhar Sharma , the founder and CEO of Paytm, recently raised alarms about the increasing dominance of AI-generated content on social media. His concerns, shared through posts on X (formerly Twitter), highlight the complexities and challenges of navigating a digital landscape where human and AI-generated content are becoming indistinguishable.On X, Sharma expressed his unease about the implications of AI-generated content for social media platforms. He suggested the introduction of a feature that could differentiate between human-created and AI-generated posts. In his post, Sharma remarked, “Sadly, soon, you won’t know if you are talking to a human or a bot,” reflecting fears that AI could overshadow genuine human interactions in digital spaces. His sentiment resonated with many, sparking a broader discussion about the need for transparency in AI applications.Paytm CEO ’s observations stem from a report by The Guardian, which discusses how AI-generated content is flooding the internet. Data from AI detection startup Originality AI revealed that over 54% of long English-language posts on LinkedIn are now created using AI tools. This analysis examined 8,795 LinkedIn posts containing more than 100 words between 2018 and 2024. While AI’s influence on content creation was negligible in earlier years, it surged significantly in 2023, coinciding with the release of ChatGPT and the widespread availability of AI-powered writing tools.To further illustrate his concerns, Sharma shared a screenshot of Grok, an AI chatbot, suggesting responses in Hindi for one of his X posts. He humorously commented, “Bots only bots. Meet or write,” emphasizing the ubiquitous presence of AI in shaping online discourse. His post went viral, drawing reactions from users concerned about AI’s influence on the authenticity of social media interactions. Some users speculated about a future where AI dominates corporate and digital communication, while others envisioned tools that could analyze signals like grammar, response speed, and content creation dates to identify AI-generated posts.
Article Summary: Vijay Shekhar Sharma, the founder and CEO of Paytm, recently raised alarms about the increasing dominance of AI-generated content on social media. His post went viral, drawing reactions from users concerned about AI’s influence on the authenticity of social media interactions. His sentiment resonated with many, sparking a broader discussion.

Article Title: Dunzo services go down as co-founder Kabeer Biswas joins Flipkart; website now reads this ‘error’ message
Article Text: Reliance-backed hyperlocal delivery platform Dunzo has gone offline shortly after its remaining co-founder and CEO, Kabeer Biswas, departed the company to join Flipkart. Additionally, the company's creditors have taken legal action, approaching the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) over unpaid dues.The departure of Kabeer Biswas, the last remaining co-founder, underscores the turmoil within the company. Former executives, including co-founders Mukund Jha and Dalvir Suri, had already exited the company, leaving behind a depleted workforce.As the quick commerce industry continues to evolve, Dunzo's decline serves as a cautionary tale for startups navigating the competitive landscape. Article Title: Microsoft creates new AI engineering division, read CEO Satya Nadella's welcome note to employees for head Jay Parikh
Article Text:
As we begin the new year, it’s clear that we’re entering the next innings of this AI platform shift. 2025 will be about model-forward applications that reshape all application categories. More so than any previous platform shift, every layer of the application stack will be impacted. It’s akin to GUI, internet servers, and cloud-native databases all being introduced into the app stack simultaneously. Thirty years of change is being compressed into three years!

We will build agentic applications with memory, entitlements, and action space that will inherit powerful model capabilities. And we will adapt these capabilities for enhanced performance and safety across roles, business processes, and industry domains. Further, how we build, deploy, and maintain code for these AI applications is also fundamentally changing and becoming agentic.

This is leading to a new AI-first app stack — one with new UI/UX patterns, runtimes to build with agents, orchestrate multiple agents, and a reimagined management and observability layer. In this world, Azure must become the infrastructure for AI, while we build our AI platform and developer tools — spanning Azure AI Foundry, GitHub, and VS Code — on top of it. In other words, our AI platform and tools will come together to create agents, and these agents will come together to change every SaaS application category, and building custom applications will be driven by software (i.e. “service as software”).

The good news is that we have been working at this for more than two years and have learned a lot in terms of the systems, app platform, and tools required for the AI era. To more rapidly and boldly advance our roadmap across each of these layers, we are creating a new engineering organization: CoreAI – Platform and Tools.

This new division will bring together Dev Div, AI Platform, and some key teams from the Office of the CTO (AI Supercomputer, AI Agentic Runtimes, and Engineering Thrive), with the mission to build the end-to-end Copilot & AI stack for both our first-party and third-party customers to build and run AI apps and agents. This group will also build out

GitHub Copilot

, thus having a tight feedback loop between the leading AI-first product and the AI platform to motivate the stack and its roadmap.

Jay Parikh will lead this group as EVP of CoreAI – Platform and Tools, with Eric Boyd, Jason Taylor, Julia Liuson, Tim Bozarth, and their respective teams reporting to Jay.

Jay will work closely with Scott, Rajesh, Charlie, Mustafa, and Kevin to optimize our entire tech stack for both performance and efficiency. Additionally, Jay and team will lead our progress and work around developer productivity and Engineering Thrive across the company.

As our cloud infrastructure business continues to grow and scale to become Microsoft’s largest business, Scott will continue to lead Cloud + AI to ensure we’re delivering the quality, security, and innovation that our customers and partners count on for their most mission-critical applications, databases, and AI workloads.

Ultimately, we must remember that our internal organizational boundaries are meaningless to both our customers and to our competitors. When we talk about operating as One Microsoft, we are effectively talking about how we are continually increasing our customer focus, raising the bar on our innovation, and driving accountability, so we can truly live up to our mission.

Our success in this next phase will be determined by having the best AI platform, tools, and infrastructure. We have a lot of work to do and a tremendous opportunity ahead, and together, I’m looking forward to building what comes next.

Satya

Article Title: Maha Kumbh: Why Steve Jobs’ wife Laurene Powell missed holy dip

Article Title: Nvidia slams Biden government’s new chip rules, calls them "unprecedented and misguided"
Article Text:
Representative Image

Nvidia praises Donald Trump’s first term as he returns to White House

The Biden administration unveiled new restrictions on AI chip exports days before swearing in of the new administration, drawing sharp criticism from industry leader Nvidia , which praised President-elect Donald Trump's policies (in his first stint) while condemning the new regulations.The Commerce Department's 168-page "Interim Final Rule on AI Diffusion" creates a three-tiered system for GPU exports, with the strictest controls affecting China and other countries of concern. The rules would limit GPU shipments to most nations to 100,000 units without special approval.Only 18 close U.S. allies, including the UK, Japan, and South Korea, would have unrestricted access to advanced AI chips. Countries designated as "of concern," including China, Russia, and Iran, face complete bans on receiving the most advanced GPUs."In the wrong hands, powerful AI systems have the potential to exacerbate significant national security risks," the White House said in its announcement, citing concerns about weapons development and surveillance capabilities.Nvidia, which controls approximately 90% of the AI chip market, responded with unusually pointed criticism. The company's VP of government affairs, Ned Finkle, called the rules "unprecedented and misguided," arguing they would "derail innovation and economic growth worldwide."In a statement, Nvidia praised Trump's first term for "laying the foundation for America's current strength and success in AI" while characterizing Biden's rules as "regulatory morass."The regulations include a 120-day comment period but are set to take effect before President-elect Trump takes office. The rules' fate remains uncertain, though they have garnered some Republican support, including from House Select Committee on China members John Moolenaar and Raja Krishnamoorthi.Industry experts are divided on the impact. While some argue the rules could push countries toward Chinese alternatives, others like "Chip War" author Chris Miller suggest they may primarily redirect data center construction toward U.S. firms rather than reducing overall GPU demand.
Article Summary: Biden administration unveiled new restrictions on AI chip exports days before swearing in of new administration. Only 18 close U.S. allies, including the UK, Japan, and South Korea, would have unrestricted access to advanced AI chips. Countries designated as "of concern," including China, Russia, and Iran, face complete bans.

Article Title: Microsoft layoffs: “No, not in India,” says Microsoft's India and South Asia head Puneet Chandok
Article Text:
This is a representational image

Microsoft announces $3 billion investment in AI and cloud expansion in India

Microsoft's India and South Asia head Puneet Chandok has 'good news' for company's employees in India. The company's India operations will not be impacted by the latest round of job cuts at Microsoft. When asked about the reported Microsoft layoffs , Puneet Chandok, President, Microsoft India and South Asia, told Hindu Businessline, “No, not in India.” “We are engaged in so many projects. In fact, for all of India, more jobs are being created,” Chandok added.CNBC recently reported that Microsoft is cutting more jobs. "Microsoft is cutting a small percentage of jobs across departments, based on performance," said the report. Microsoft has confirmed the job cuts. “At Microsoft we focus on high-performance talent,” a Microsoft spokesperson said in an email to CNBC on Wednesday. “We are always working on helping people learn and grow. When people are not performing, we take the appropriate action.”Microsoft’s latest round of job cuts are reported to affect less than 1% of employees. The number is lower compared to the company's downsizing exercises in the last two years. In early 2023, Microsoft cut 10,000 jobs. In January 2024, three months after completing the $75.4 billion Activision Blizzard acquisition, Microsoft’s gaming unit shed 1,900 jobs.Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella was in India recently as part of Microsoft's AI India Tour. Nadella announced that Microsoft will invest $3 billion to expand its cloud computing and artificial intelligence capabilities in India. Nadella said the USD 3 billion investment in India would be the "single-largest expansion" done in the country. "The diffusion rate of AI in India is exciting."Speaking to the media at the event, Chandok said that the $3 billion investment announced by Nadella will be on building tech, infrastructure and AI capacity and also on building the human capital in this country. "In the last 12 months Microsoft has been a copilot to making AI a reality in India, taking it from boardrooms to classrooms, commerce to communities, and finance to farmers. Today's announcement strengthens our belief in India's potential and our resolve to equip the country with the resources and future-ready skills needed to excel in the global marketplace. We will continue to use AI to unlock possibilities for the next few decades and ensure communities across the country have access to the compute they need to prosper in the AI era," Chandhok said.Microsoft currently operates three data centre regions in India and is set to launch a fourth by the year 2026. Microsoft provides its cloud computing services under the Azure brand name. It has over 60 Azure regions comprising more than 300 data centres.

Article Title: For the first time ever Tesla overtakes Audi in global car sales; what is hurting one of the world's biggest premium car maker
Article Text:
What is hurting Audi

Tesla surpassed Audi, one of Germany's flagship premium car brands, in global sales last year for the first time ever. Tesla reportedly delivered 1.79 million vehicles, edging out Audi, which saw a 12% drop to 1.67 million units in 2024. Tesla managed to beat Audi despite falling short of its own delivery targets.This shift underscores the challenges facing traditional automakers in the evolving automotive landscape. While Tesla experienced its first annual delivery decline in over a decade and narrowly maintained its lead over BYD in the fully electric vehicle (EV) market, its significant growth in recent years positioned it to capitalize on the struggles of established players like Audi. The popularity of Tesla's Model Y SUV, which is slated for a refresh this year, has been a key driver of its success.Audi's decline is attributed to several factors. The brand faced intensifying competition in both Europe and China, coupled with weaker-than-expected demand for its electric vehicles. In China, a key market for luxury brands, the economic recovery remains uncertain, and domestic manufacturers are increasingly competing in the premium segment. In Europe, reduced EV subsidies in several countries have dampened sales. These market pressures contributed to a wave of profit warnings last year from major German automakers, including Volkswagen (Audi's parent company), Mercedes-Benz, and BMW.Audi experienced sales declines across key markets, including Germany, China, and North America. Deliveries of its fully electric models also fell by 8%, reaching approximately 164,000 units. In response to slowing sales, manufacturers have begun adjusting production. Volkswagen has reduced capacity for its core brand, and Audi plans to close its Brussels plant due to weak demand for the electric Q8 e-tron SUV produced there.To revitalize sales, Audi plans to refresh several models this year, including the A7 sedan and Q3 SUV. CEO Gernot Döllner also announced plans to introduce "numerous new plug-in hybrids" in an effort to broaden the brand's appeal and address the shifting market dynamics.
Article Summary: Tesla surpassed Audi, one of Germany's flagship premium car brands, in global sales last year for the first time ever. Tesla reportedly delivered 1.79 million vehicles, edging out Audi, which saw a 12% drop to 1.67 million units in 2024. Tesla managed to beat Audi despite falling short of its own delivery targets.
